More than half a million people marched in silence through the streets of central Madrid tonight to protest a campaign of violence by Basque separatists.

Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez, a Socialist, carried a banner with opposition politicians including his main rival in the March 3 general election, the center-right Popular Party leader, Jose Maria Aznar. Polls have shown Mr. Aznar ahead of Mr. Gonzalez, who has led the Government for 13 years.

Political parties and unions called the protest after the Basque guerrilla group ETA, the initials for Basque Homeland and Freedom in the Basque language, shot a law professor in his office at the Autonomous University in Madrid last Wednesday. The victim, Francisco Tomas y Valiente, was a former chief of Spain's constitutional court.

The march was led by relatives of victims of guerrilla violence. Hundreds of people streamed from surrounding streets to join the march. The police estimated that there were 600,000 people at the start of the march.
